name: Perfect Prey: A Coercive Control Podcast

episodes.title: The Weaponization of Children in Coercive Control
episodes.description:
In this solo episode of Perfect Prey, I explore one of the most heartbreaking dynamics of coercive control: the weaponization of children.

Children rely on their parents for safety, stability, and unconditional love. But when a predatory parent is operating within the family system, attachment can become fractured. Instead of growing up with secure connection, children are often indoctrinated into false narratives, exposed to subtle undermining, and pulled into loyalty binds they cannot cognitively or emotionally process.

I explain how coercive control is the underpinning of all forms of abuse — psychological, legal, financial, physical, and emotional — and how, when an abuser can no longer control their partner, they often shift to controlling through the child.

We’ll talk about:

How attachment is formed — and how it can be fractured

Why children may come home dysregulated, angry, or oppositional

How subtle undermining and false narratives are planted

The difference between alienation rhetoric and attachment fracture

Why predatory parents rely on retaliation and loyalty conflicts

How protective parents can create “roadblocks” to manipulation

What it means to respond instead of react — even when you are traumatized

This episode is especially for protective parents navigating post-separation abuse and family court dynamics. The reality is painful: children are often placed in impossible positions, forced into emotional roles they should never have to carry.

But there are ways to respond differently.

If you are watching your child struggle, unravel, or lash out after time with the other parent, this episode will help you understand what may be happening beneath the surface — and how to stay grounded in your role as the secure base.

Protective parents are doing some of the hardest work there is. You are not alone.

episodes.title: When Therapy Tells You to Change Instead of Naming the Abuse
episodes.description:
In this episode, Dr. Christine Cocchiola discusses something many survivors quietly experience:

Being told — sometimes even in therapy — that if they just changed a little more, tried a little harder, or accommodated a little better… the relationship might improve.

When coercive control is present, that advice can be deeply harmful.

✨ In this video, Dr. Christine explores:

Trauma bonding and intermittent reinforcement

“Shapeshifting” to accommodate an abusive partner

How therapy can inadvertently reinforce subjugation

Why recognizing patterns creates empowerment

The power of boundaries — even when escape is complex

How protective parents become the light guiding their children toward clarity

When you begin to see the pattern, there is power in that awareness.
Whether you choose to stay, set boundaries, or prepare to leave — clarity is different than confusion.

And for protective parents: your children are watching.
When you reclaim your agency, they see what freedom looks like.

💙 There is no judgment here. Only education, validation, and empowerment.

episodes.title: The Danger of Couples Therapy in Coercive Control
episodes.description:
In this episode, Dr. Christine Cocchiola speaks directly to both therapists and survivors about a difficult but critical truth:

Couples therapy can be dangerous when coercive control is present.

When there is a pattern of power over, inequity, and manipulation, attempting to “bring the couple together” can unintentionally:

Empower and embolden the abuser

Give false hope to the victim

Keep someone trapped in a harmful dynamic

Reinforce manipulation inside the therapy room

Dr. Christine shares her own experience of having a therapist name the abuse — and how that truth became a thread she returned to over and over again.

✨ If you are a therapist, this is a call to discern patterns of coercive control and recognize when reconciliation is not the goal — safety is.
✨ If you are a survivor, this is your reminder to listen to your body. Patterns matter. Your intuition matters.

If you are a professional and want to deepen your understanding, Dr. C offers a comprehensive Coercive Control Professionals Training (12 CEs) designed to equip clinicians with the tools needed to navigate these complex dynamics.

💙 You are not alone. Clarity is power.

episodes.title: When Apologies Aren’t Change: Listening to Your Body
episodes.description:
In this episode, Dr. Christine Cocchiola explores why so many survivors feel compelled to give abusers another chance—and why patterns of behavior matter far more than apologies or promises to change.

Many abusive partners beg, apologize, promise therapy, and momentarily improve. But when harmful behaviors repeat—verbal degradation, infidelity, intimidation, or DARVO—those patterns tell a deeper truth.

✨ In this video, Dr. Christine discusses:

Why survivors disconnect from their body’s signals

How disassociation becomes a survival strategy

The impact of repeated “second chances” on children

How children mirror the regulation and suppression they observe

Why children often become weaponized as proxies in abuse

Navigating impossible choices without judgment

This conversation is not about shaming survivors for staying or leaving.
It is about listening to the body, recognizing patterns, and understanding how children absorb and adapt to unsafe relational dynamics.

💙 There is no judgment here—only clarity, compassion, and support.

episodes.title: Coercive Control Is a War of Attrition with Laura Richards
episodes.description:
In this episode of Perfect Prey, I’m joined by Laura Richards, a criminal behavioral analyst, former New Scotland Yard specialist, and one of the leading global voices on coercive control. Laura has been instrumental in changing laws on stalking and coercive control in the UK and internationally, and her work has helped shape policy, legislation, and professional practice worldwide.

We explore why coercive control is not about isolated incidents, but a patterned strategy of domination, entrapment, and power imbalance. Laura explains why coercive control is best understood as a war of attrition, how patriarchy and misogyny shape institutional responses, and why women and children are so often disbelieved—even when the evidence is present.

This conversation examines how legal systems, family courts, and law enforcement frequently fail victims and survivors, particularly at the point of separation, when risk escalates most dramatically. We also discuss why coercive control must be criminalized, why gender matters in risk assessment, and how language itself can either obscure or reveal abuse.

What we cover
What coercive control really is and why it’s a patterned form of abuse
Why victims and survivors are often disbelieved by systems meant to protect them
Coercive control as “murders and suicides in slow motion”
The role of patriarchy, entitlement, and power imbalance in abuse
Why separation is the most dangerous time for women and children
How family courts can become a tool of post-separation abuse
Why protecting children requires protecting the non-abusive parent
The urgent need to criminalize coercive control globally

Why listen
If you are a survivor, protective parent, clinician, attorney, advocate, or policymaker, this episode offers critical insight into how coercive control operates beneath the surface of relationships and systems. Laura Richards brings clarity to why abuse is so often minimized, misunderstood, or reframed—and what must change to prevent further harm.

Guest bio (short)
Laura Richards is a criminal behavioral analyst, former New Scotland Yard specialist, and a leading international expert on coercive control, stalking, and violence against women. She helped create the DASH risk assessment model, founded the National Stalking Advocacy Service (Paladin), and played a central role in criminalizing coercive control in England and Wales. Laura is the author of Policing Domestic Violence and host of the Crime Analyst and Real Crime Profile podcasts.

episodes.title: The Divorce Industrial Complex: Power, Control, and Family Court
episodes.description:
In this episode, Dr. Christine Cocchiola, licensed clinical social worker and long-time advocate for protective parents, continues the conversation about collusion within the family court system.

While not every professional lacks integrity, the reality is that too many systems benefit from prolonged conflict. As Dr. Christine explains, enormous amounts of money are generated through divorce, custody, and post-separation litigation—creating what many now call the divorce industrial complex.

These are not “high conflict” cases.
They are power-and-control cases.

✨ In this video, Dr. Christine discusses:

Why family court is not immune to systemic harm

How money often equals power in custody disputes

The use of vexatious litigation as retaliation

Why coercive control continues post-separation

Why these dynamics are happening everywhere—not just in one state or country

Why these stories must be told for young people and future families

This is why Dr. Christine helped bring forward Framed: Women in the Family Court Underworld, a collection of 22 real stories from protective mothers around the world who experienced coercive control and systemic harm.

Dr. Christine also acknowledges protective fathers and shares that support spaces for protective dads exist, because this harm is not limited to one gender.

💙 You have more influence than you realize.
You can help your children heal.

episodes.title: There Is No “High Conflict Divorce” : There Is Power & Control
episodes.description:
In this video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola, licensed clinical social worker and long-time advocate for protective parents, addresses one of the most misunderstood and damaging narratives in the family court system: the myth of “high conflict divorce.”

What is often labeled as “high conflict” is, in reality, a power-over dynamic—where one parent systematically coerces, controls, and retaliates against the other. Over time, survivors may appear reactive, dysregulated, or adversarial, not because this reflects who they are, but because anyone trapped long enough will eventually push back.

Dr. Christine explains why protective parents—particularly protective mothers—are so often framed, disbelieved, and pathologized in family court, while perpetrators with a pattern of coercive control are overlooked or even rewarded.

✨ In this episode, Dr. Christine discusses:

Why “high conflict” is a misleading label

How power and control show up in family court

Why survivors are often not believed

How victims behave outside abusive dynamics

The role of retaliation and vexatious litigation

The divorce industrial complex and systemic harm

Why character patterns—not reactions—matter

This work is deeply personal and deeply professional. It is why Dr. Christine co-authored Framed: Women in the Family Court Underworld, sharing 22 real stories of protective mothers from around the world who were harmed not only by abusers—but by systems meant to protect.

💙 If this resonates, please subscribe and share.

episodes.title: Predict. Prepare. Protect. Surviving an Abuser’s Retaliation
episodes.description:
In today’s video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola explains why children — and even adults — can seem to “flip on a dime” back toward an abusive parent after gaining clarity.

This shift is not confusion or weakness. It is the result of intermittent reinforcement, the same tactic that once kept you stuck. A small moment of kindness, charm, or calm can cause the nervous system to lower its guard — and abusers know exactly when and how to do this.

Dr. Christine also discusses why family court becomes a stage for retaliation. These individuals are not simply “high conflict” — they are drawn to conflict. They are adversarial, inflexible, and energized by power struggles. Their goal is not resolution. Their goal is punishment.

✨ In this episode, Dr. Christine discusses:

Why children can revert after gaining clarity

How intermittent reinforcement works in abusive dynamics

Why abusers retaliate when exposed

How systems are often manipulated to continue abuse

Why family court is especially dangerous

The difference between conflict and antagonism

The 3 Ps for survival: Predict, Prepare, Protect

Dr. Christine emphasizes the importance of seeing the freight train coming. Until you recognize the pattern and get off the tracks, the damage can be devastating. Strategy is not manipulation — it is protection.

💙 If this resonates, please subscribe and share.
Clarity saves lives. Preparation reduces harm.

episodes.title: That’s Not Your Child: It’s Coercive Control
episodes.description:
In today’s video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola speaks directly to protective parents who are struggling to recognize their child beneath aggressive, dismissive, or heartbreaking behavior.

Children raised in coercively controlling family systems become entangled in the abuser’s web. The behaviors protective parents see — aggression, withdrawal, hostility — are often not expressions of who the child truly is, but survival responses shaped by coercion, fear, and control.

Dr. Christine clarifies an important distinction:
Most children are not fully indoctrinated against their protective parent. Many are acquiescing, some are aligning, and some temporarily identify with the aggressor. True estrangement is far rarer than most people believe.

She shares a powerful story of a protective mother who was forced to let go after systems failed — and how years later, her child returned, ready to reconnect once the control loosened.

✨ In this episode, Dr. Christine discusses:

Why behavior under coercive control is not the child’s true self

The difference between estrangement, acquiescence, and alignment

How identifying with the aggressor is a survival response

Why shame only deepens harm

The power of saying: “That wasn’t your fault. That wasn’t my fault.”

How steadiness, understanding, and patience create space for reconnection

Dr. Christine reminds protective parents: your child is still there. They are submerged, entangled, and trying to breathe — but love and attachment do not disappear.

💙 If this resonates, please subscribe and share.
Your understanding matters more than you know.

episodes.title: Coercive Control is the Foundation of Most Domestic Abuse
episodes.description:
In today’s video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola breaks down what coercive control actually is — and why so many victims don’t recognize it while they’re living inside it.

Historically, abuse has been understood through a violent incident model, focusing on physical harm. But coercive control is a non-physical violence model, rooted in power and control. It slowly and insidiously erodes autonomy, voice, and a person’s ability to be themselves.

Dr. Christine explains how coercive controllers often seek out people who are:

Accommodating

Optimistic

Relationship-oriented

Willing to work hard to make things “better”

Because coercive control is nuanced, many survivors look back only later and recognize the signs — gaslighting, mockery, intimidation, isolation, threats, and consequences for simply expressing feelings or disagreement.

✨ In this episode, Dr. Christine discusses:

Why abuse is about power and control, not just violence

How coercive control can exist without physical harm

Common tactics like mockery, minimization, and revenge

Why family court often becomes a stage for coercive controllers

How victims lose personal power over time

Why children are not just witnesses — but victims

How children learn to regulate themselves through fear and appeasement

Dr. Christine emphasizes that coercive control within the family system is child abuse, even when no physical violence is present. Children learn to walk on eggshells just as the adult victim does — and that harm is often unacknowledged by systems.

💙 If this resonates, please subscribe and share.
Naming coercive control is a critical step toward clarity and healing.

episodes.title: Child Sexual Abuse, Grooming, and the Systems That Fail Children — with Andrew Carpenter
episodes.description:
In this episode of Perfect Prey, I’m joined by Andrew Carpenter, a solicitor and partner at Webster Lawyers in Australia, widely known for his work holding child sexual abuse perpetrators accountable and advocating for systemic reform.

Andrew and I have a frank, uncomfortable, and deeply necessary conversation about child sexual abuse, grooming, coercive control, and the institutional failures that continue to endanger children. We explore how child predators use the same grooming tactics as coercive controllers, how technology and AI have dramatically increased access to abuse material, and why legal systems—including family courts—so often fail to protect children and the parents trying to keep them safe.

This episode centers the reality that child sexual abuse is not rare, not accidental, and not a crime of opportunity—it is intentional, patterned, and enabled by silence, disbelief, and systemic blind spots.

What we cover
How child sexual abuse perpetrators groom children, families, and institutions
Why all child predators use coercive control and relational grooming tactics
The disturbing accessibility of child abuse material online
How technology, AI, and social media are being weaponized against children
Why most abuse occurs within trusted relationships and family systems
The failures of criminal courts and family courts to protect child victims
Why lack of physical evidence does not mean abuse did not occur
Warning signs, behavioral red flags, and changes parents should not ignore
How shame, fear, and silence protect perpetrators—not children
What meaningful prevention, accountability, and reform must address

Why listen
If you are a survivor, protective parent, clinician, attorney, educator, or advocate, this episode provides critical insight into how child sexual abuse actually operates—and why so many children are disbelieved, retraumatized, or returned to unsafe environments. Andrew’s work exposes how deeply embedded these harms are within systems that claim to protect children, and why uncomfortable conversations are essential to change.

Guest bio (short)
Andrew Carpenter is a solicitor and partner at Webster Lawyers in Australia, specializing in child sexual abuse litigation and survivor advocacy. He is widely recognized for challenging institutional failures, advocating for legal reform, and amplifying survivor voices in cases where children have been silenced or ignored. His work focuses on accountability, deterrence, and systemic change to better protect children.

episodes.title: Why Children Dissociate From Abuse: Trauma Bonding Explained
episodes.description:
In today’s video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola continues the conversation on trauma bonding in children by focusing on dissociation and cognitive dissonance — two powerful survival responses that help children cope with being forced into unsafe relationships.

Children living under coercive control are often required by systems to continue contact with an abusive parent. Faced with the unbearable reality that a caregiver is harmful — while still needing to survive visits — the brain adapts. Dissociation becomes a way to reduce pain, and over time, permissive and neglectful parenting can reinforce this process.

Dr. Christine explains how:

Dissociation helps children survive overwhelming pain

Cognitive dissonance makes harm feel “normal”

Permissiveness and neglect deepen trauma bonds

Gaslighting can turn inward, leading children to doubt their own reality

Trauma bonds are neurologically reinforced over time

She also speaks to the grief and loss protective parents carry — the grief of recognizing how deeply children have been harmed and how profoundly unfair this reality is. As Dr. Christine notes, grief doesn’t disappear; we grow around it.

💙 If this resonates, please subscribe and share.
Your clarity matters. Your grief is real. And your steadiness helps more than you know.

episodes.title: Why Children Trauma Bond to an Abusive Parent
episodes.description:
In today’s video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola talks about one of the most painful and confusing realities for protective parents: children becoming trauma bonded to an abusive parent.

Trauma bonding in children looks different than it does in adult relationships. The abusive person is not a partner — it is their caretaker. Attachment to a parent is biologically driven and designed for survival, which makes trauma bonds with caregivers especially powerful and difficult to break.

Dr. Christine explains how children often live in a dissociated state, forgetting or minimizing the harm they experienced — even when they heard violence, felt fear in their bodies, or lived in constant instability. This forgetting is not denial; it is the brain’s survival strategy.

✨ In this episode, Dr. Christine discusses:

Why attachment to a caregiver is biologically reinforced

How trauma bonding helps children survive unsafe environments

Why children dissociate from painful memories

How coercive control shapes a child’s beliefs about the safe parent

Why power — not love — keeps children tied to the abuser

Why children forgive at high rates even after recognizing abuse

episodes.title: Protecting Children From Grooming What Every Parent Needs to Know
episodes.description:
In today’s video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola addresses one of the most difficult — and most necessary — conversations parents must have: grooming, child sexual abuse, and coercive control.

Dr. Christine explains that while not all coercive controllers are pedophiles, all pedophiles use the same grooming tactics as coercive controllers. Grooming is not sudden or obvious. It is calculated, relational, and often carried out by adults children know, trust, or even love.

She also addresses an important truth: children are never responsible for protecting themselves. Adults must be held accountable. And yet, we live in a world where systems often fail, predators are not always stopped, and parents are left navigating real risk without support.

This is why Dr. Christine discusses how to give children a developmentally appropriate safety toolbox — not to place responsibility on them, but to help them retain voice, body awareness, and agency when something feels off.

✨ In this episode, Dr. Christine discusses:

Why grooming is a form of coercive control

How predators select and groom children

Why abuse often doesn’t “feel scary” to a child

The importance of teaching children there are no secrets

Why children must know they will always be believed

How to talk about body safety using clear, correct language

Why intuition and body signals matter

The reality that even informed children can still be harmed — and why that is never their fault

Dr. Christine also invites viewers to explore her podcast, Perfect Prey, where adult and child victims share their lived experiences of coercive control, grooming, and survival.

In today’s video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola speaks directly to protective parents navigating one of the hardest realities imaginable: parenting children who have been coercively controlled and weaponized by an abusive parent.

Dr. Christine explains why co-parenting is not possible in these dynamics and why so many protective parents feel confused, overwhelmed, and unsupported. From permissive and neglectful parenting to the misuse of technology and lack of structure, abusers often compromise a child’s developing brain — not for the child’s benefit, but to harm the adult victim.

Children may appear to prefer the abusive parent because that environment offers unlimited freedom without responsibility. When the protective parent provides structure, safety, and boundaries, they are often met with resistance — not because they are doing something wrong, but because the child has been harmed.

Why abusers weaponize children from day one

How permissive and neglectful parenting is used as a control tactic

Why children lose agency and autonomy under coercive control

Why your expectations must change when parenting abused children

The importance of connecting instead of correcting

Why radical acceptance is essential for survival and healing

Why this is unacknowledged child abuse

In today’s video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola explains why love bombing and grooming are central features of coercive control—and why abuse is so often invisible to the outside world.

In the UK, love bombing is formally recognized as part of coercive control. Abusers groom their victims, their children, and entire communities over time. Dr. Christine shares how coercive control often intensifies after separation, why leaving does not automatically make victims safer, and how abusers escalate once they feel they are losing control. Why love bombing is a grooming tactic

How abusers hide rage beneath charm

Why abuse escalates after separation

Why victims are often not believed

How grooming impacts children and extended family

The difference between personal power and power over

Why community is essential for survival and healing

episodes.description:
In this episode of Perfect Prey, I’m joined by Tonia Bales, author of When You See It: How I Outsmarted and Outlasted Dirty John. Tonia shares her story as the first wife of the man later known to the world as “Dirty John”—long before the podcast, Netflix series, or public recognition of who he really was.
Tonia describes how coercive control, deception, and manipulation unfolded inside her marriage, how she began uncovering her husband’s double life, and how the legal and family court systems failed to protect her and her children. This conversation offers a powerful look at how predators hide in plain sight, how survivors are often DARVO’d when they speak up, and how children become collateral damage in abusive systems.

Life with Dirty John before the world knew his name


How predators identify and target “perfect prey”


Early warning signs, red flags, and deception hidden in plain sight


DARVO tactics and false accusations used to silence victims


Substance abuse, professional abuse of power, and systemic failure


Family court, coercive control, and the weaponization of children


Protective parenting, resilience, and healing after profound trauma

episodes.title: The Tale of Two Children: When Abuse Changes Who Your Child Becomes
episodes.description:
In today’s video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola speaks to one of the most painful realities for protective parents — the experience of feeling like you’re raising two different children.

The child you knew — the tender, playful, trusting little one — and the child who now feels angry, withdrawn, dysregulated, or aggressive toward the very parent they are safest with. Dr. Christine explains why this shift is not a personality change or a parenting failure, but a trauma response to coercive control and unacknowledged child abuse.

Children living in abusive family systems are often operating from the survival part of the brain. They don’t feel safe. They can’t be fully themselves. And because it is unsafe to direct anger or fear toward the abusive parent, those feelings are often displaced onto the protective parent.

In this episode, Dr. Christine explores:

Why children can feel like “different kids” after abuse

How trauma fractures a child’s sense of safety and identity

Why anger, withdrawal, or aggression are forms of self-defense

The grief parents feel when the child they imagined changes

How personal power helps parents “level up” instead of collapsing

Why healing is about helping children become the healthiest version of themselves — even under horrific circumstances

She also highlights her “Connect the Dots” video series, created for children who are beginning to recognize and name their experiences of abuse in a way that feels safe and validating.

💙 If this resonates, please subscribe and share.
You are not imagining what you’re seeing — and you are not alone in this.

episodes.title: Personal Power vs. Power Over: What Abusers Don’t Want You to Understand
episodes.description:
In today’s video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola explores an essential distinction that is often distorted in coercively controlling family systems: the difference between personal power and power over.

Personal power is about agency, voice, and healthy boundaries. It is the ability to assert yourself, care for your children, and create structure that supports growth and independence. Power over, on the other hand, is what abusers use — control, domination, and coercion.

Dr. Christine explains why, when protective parents begin asserting healthy boundaries, abusers often accuse them of being “controlling.” This tactic is frequently used not only against partners, but also against children — where structure, support, and expectations are reframed as harm.

She discusses:

Why asserting personal power can trigger backlash

How abusers co-opt the language of control

The impact this has on children’s perception of the safe parent

Why children need agency and structure

How teaching children personal power protects them long-term

Dr. Christine also invites listeners to explore her podcast, Perfect Prey, where she interviews survivors, professionals, and advocates — including David Challen and Anne Burgess — to deepen understanding of coercive control and its impact across the lifespan.

💙 If this resonates, please subscribe and share.
Personal power is not something to apologize for — it is something to reclaim.

episodes.title: The Unthinkable: A Child’s View of Coercive Control with David Challen
episodes.description:
n this episode of Perfect Prey, I’m joined by David Challen, author of The Unthinkable, who shares his experience growing up as a child inside a coercively controlling family system. David offers a rare and powerful perspective on coercive control through the eyes of a child—long before there was language to describe abuse, and long before systems were willing to see it.

This conversation explores how coercive control creates an atmosphere of fear, vigilance, humiliation, and emotional captivity within families, even when there is no visible violence. David reflects on the early intuition that something was wrong, the “rot in the house” that others could not see, and how children normalize danger in order to survive. Together, we examine the intergenerational harm caused by coercive control and why children are not passive witnesses, but co-victims.

What we cover
What coercive control looks and feels like through the eyes of a child
How children sense danger, imbalance, and domination long before abuse is named
The normalization of mockery, humiliation, fear, and emotional subservience within families
Why coercive control is not “hidden abuse,” but a trajectory of escalating harm
How long-term psychological domination strips autonomy, identity, and safety over time
The concept of “systemic degradation” and how victims are worn down across years or decades
Why victim retaliation is often misunderstood, mislabeled, and criminalized
The long-term impact on adult child survivors and protective parents


Why listen
 If you are a survivor, protective parent, adult child survivor, clinician, or legal professional, this episode offers critical insight into how coercive control operates inside families and why children are deeply affected—even when abuse is not outwardly visible. This conversation brings clarity to experiences that are often minimized, misunderstood, or dismissed, and highlights why coercive control must be recognized as the foundation of all abuse.

Guest bio (short)
 David Challen is an author, speaker, and campaigner on domestic abuse and coercive control. He is the author of The Unthinkable, which tells the story of growing up in a coercively controlled household and the devastating impact of long-term psychological abuse on children and families. David is a prominent advocate for greater recognition of coercive control and has spoken widely about intergenerational harm, survivor justice, and systemic failure.

episodes.title: 3 Manifestations of Trauma in Children of Coercive Control
episodes.description:
In this video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola—licensed clinical social worker and coauthor of Framed: A Woman in the Family Court Underworld—explores three common manifestations of trauma in children raised within coercively controlling, narcissistic, and abusive family systems.

Drawing from decades of clinical work and the lived experiences of protective parents, Dr. Christine explains how children adapt to unsafe environments—and how these adaptations can follow them into adolescence and adulthood.

✨ The three trauma responses discussed:

Significant anxiety — difficulty regulating, freezing during everyday tasks, and feeling unsafe in the body

Dissociation — a “forgetting” of harm as a protective survival response

Trauma bonding — emotional attachment to the abusive parent, including forgetting the secure attachment once shared with the protective parent

Dr. Christine also shares an upcoming healing opportunity with Nadine Macaluso, where adult and childhood trauma bonding will be addressed in a supportive setting at Kripalu Center for Yoga & Health.

This conversation is meant to validate what protective parents are seeing, reduce self-blame, and bring clarity to behaviors that are often misunderstood.

episodes.title: When Your Child Is Distant During the Holidays: Stay the Safe Parent
episodes.description:
In today’s video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola speaks directly to protective parents navigating one of the most painful experiences of all — holidays without your child, or holidays where your love feels unreciprocated or rejected.

Dr. Christine acknowledges how deeply difficult Christmas, Hanukkah, and other holidays can be after coercive control, post-separation abuse, or estrangement. She offers gentle guidance on why remaining steady matters more than protecting yourself from rejection.

She encourages parents to continue sending:

A simple card

A small, thoughtful gift

A brief message of unconditional love

—not to get a response, not to provoke guilt, and not to manipulate, but to anchor safety and consistency.

Children impacted by coercive control are highly sensitive to tone and intention. Even well-meant statements can be perceived as manipulative if they hint at jealousy, resentment, or expectation. Dr. Christine explains why less is more, and why unconditional love — without explanation or pressure — is the most powerful message you can send.

✨ In this video, Dr. Christine discusses:

Why holidays are especially painful for protective parents

When to send a card or gift even if it may be rejected

How certain phrases can be misinterpreted

Why steadiness builds long-term safety

How unconditional love supports eventual reconnection

💙 If this resonates, please subscribe and share.
You are not alone, and your steadiness matters more than you know.

episodes.title: “It Wasn’t You”: Why Abuse Happens to Good, Agreeable People
episodes.description:
In today’s video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola speaks directly to protective parents asking one of the most painful questions:
“Why did this happen to me?”

Dr. Christine explains a critical truth — if you had met someone with your values, empathy, and relational style, this would not have happened. Abuse does not occur because of who you are. It happens because of who the abuser is.

Abusers are often antagonistic, highly conflict-oriented, disagreeable, and intolerant of autonomy. Over time, through gaslighting, intimidation, isolation, and manipulation, they force their partner to become smaller and smaller — not because the partner is weak, but because survival required constant regulation.

Dr. Christine also discusses:

Why abusers escalate post-separation

How trauma bonds keep people hoping the “good version” will return

Why clarity often comes only after the abuse intensifies

The role of neuroticism and obsession in post-separation punishment

Why radical acceptance is necessary for healing

Why this experience has nothing to do with your worth, intelligence, or strength

As Dr. Christine reminds viewers: “It’s not you. It’s them.”

episodes.title: How to Rebuild Empathy in Children Impacted by Coercive Control
episodes.description:
In today’s video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola discusses how to rebuild empathy in children who have been harmed by coercive control and predatory parenting.

Many protective parents wonder why their child seems unkind, distant, or uninterested when the parent is hurt, tired, or struggling. Dr. Christine explains that this is often not a lack of care — it is the result of oppression, entitlement, and emotional conditioning by the abusive parent, who teaches the child not to extend themselves toward the safe parent.

Empathy doesn’t return through confrontation or guilt. It is rebuilt through small, intentional, attuned opportunities that allow the child to succeed rather than fail.

In this video, Dr. Christine explains:

Why children of coercive control lose empathy skills

How oppression and permissive parenting disrupt development

Why timing matters more than rules

The difference between regulating yourself vs. walking on eggshells

How to create success-based opportunities for empathy

Why these children are often not at their chronological age

How to rebuild competence without power struggles

These children have lost skills — not values. With patience, creativity, and attunement, empathy can be gently restored.

episodes.title: Coercive Control Starts Day One: Even Experts Can Miss It
episodes.description:
In this deeply personal episode, Dr. Christine Cocchiola shares her own story — how she spent decades studying, teaching, and treating coercive control, yet did not recognize that she and her two children were living in it themselves.

Like so many protective parents, she worked endlessly to “fix” the marriage, unaware that her children were being indoctrinated with false narratives about her from day one. It was only years after the final separation that she learned just how long the coercive control had been shaping their beliefs, behaviors, and sense of identity.

Dr. Christine explains why coercive control is the underpinning of all abuse, why even the most trained professionals can miss it, and why children living in these systems develop chronic self-doubt, social anxiety, and difficulty being authentically themselves.

She also discusses:

episodes.title: Coercion, Cult dynamics & Survival with Sarma Melngailis
episodes.description:
In this episode of Perfect Prey, I speak with Sarma Melngailis, author of The Girl with the Duck Tattoo and the central figure in the documentary Bad Vegan. Sarma shares her lived experience of sustained psychological coercion, how it felt to be worn down and re-anchored in someone else’s reality, and what the recovery process looks like after a relationship that functioned much like a one-on-one cult.
What we cover
How coercive control can operate like psychological warfare and the tactics that make it feel impossible to leave.


Why intelligent, accomplished people can become victims: the slow wearing down, mirroring, and exploitation of hopes and vulnerabilities.


The parallels between cult dynamics and one-on-one coercive relationships—why isolation and repeated micro-assaults change perception and decision-making.


The aftermath: public shame, misrepresentation in media, and the ongoing work of reclaiming agency, safety, and reputation.


Practical reflections for survivors and protective parents: how to notice red flags early, the power of sitting with your intuition, and how healing helps rebuild boundaries and clarity.


Why listen
 Sarma’s story illustrates that coercive control is not about intelligence or credentials — it’s about a strategic, multifaceted assault on agency and reality. Whether you are a survivor, a caregiver, a clinician, or someone trying to understand how otherwise kind and competent people get trapped, this episode names the mechanisms, normalizes survivors’ reactions, and offers concrete ideas for protection and recovery.
Guest bio (short)
 Sarma Melngailis is the author of The Girl with the Duck Tattoo and the subject of the documentary Bad Vegan. She writes and speaks about her experience of coercive control and its aftermath, helping others recognize the subtle, insidious tactics used by predatory partners.

episodes.title: Reigniting Attachment: Small Shifts That Help Your Child’s Brain Heal
episodes.description:
In today’s video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola shares practical, healing-focused ways protective parents can reignite attachment with children who have been harmed, manipulated, or distanced by an abusive parent.

She explains why small environmental changes—like moving a photo, placing an old picture on the counter during breakfast, or sending a benign childhood memory by text—can awaken parts of the brain connected to safety, joy, and belonging. These moments help children reconnect to the truth of their relationship with the protective parent.

Dr. Christine also discusses why children may pull away, become non-responsive, or reject contact, and how this is often a direct result of years of coercive control—not a reflection of who you are as a parent.

To rebuild connection, she emphasizes:

✨ Using photos and shared memories to gently spark attachment
✨ Sending benign, expectation-free messages
✨ Avoiding triggers that push children into the “unsafe” brain state
✨ Understanding the difference between “walking on eggshells” with an abuser vs. regulating yourself for your child’s healing
✨ Why trying to “correct” or direct an estranged child often backfires

Children impacted by coercive control are not the same children they once were. But with compassion, regulation, and strategic connection, healing remains possible.

episodes.title: Coercive Control, Courts & “Perfect Prey” — with Dr. Ramani Durvasula
episodes.description:
In this episode of Perfect Prey I’m joined by my friend and colleague Dr. Ramani Durvasula, a clinical psychologist, author, professor, and internationally recognized expert on narcissistic abuse. We dig into why coercive control feels like imprisonment without bars, how systems (including family court) retraumatize survivors, and what survivors can do to protect themselves and their children. 
What we cover
Why coercive control is often invisible — and why the myth of “free will” makes it so hard for institutions to understand emotional abuse.

How victim-blaming and the DARVO pattern (Deny, Attack, Reverse Victim & Offender) let abusers manipulate sympathy in court.

The difference between milder narcissistic traits and the kind of malignant, coercive abuse that creates real danger and CPTSD-like responses.

Practical, trauma-informed strategies for surviving family court: what to document, when to prioritize safety over “justice,” and how to protect your children while minimizing retraumatization.


The “industrial divorce complex” — how systems and money can deepen harm, and what survivors can do strategically to preserve their safety and sense of self.

Why listen
 If you’re a survivor, a clinician, a legal professional, or someone trying to understand a loved one’s experience, this conversation names the harms you may not see on the surface and gives clear, compassionate guidance for staying safe and getting validated. You’ll hear clinical insight paired with real-world, tactical advice about custody, court behavior, and how to build a safety-first plan.

episodes.title: Why Therapy for Children of Coercive Control is NOT always the answer Part 2
episodes.description:
In this episode, Dr. Christine Cocchiola continues the conversation on why therapy can sometimes become a trap for children living under coercive control.

When children are forced into therapy while carrying a false narrative created by the abusive parent, they may feel pressured to repeat harmful statements about their safe, protective parent. Many therapists—without training in coercive control—may unintentionally affirm this narrative, not realizing the child is speaking from fear, confusion, or manipulation.

Dr. Christine explains how this dynamic can create shame, emotional discomfort, and deep internal conflict for the child. Instead of healing, they may feel trapped in a cycle of saying things they don’t believe, simply to survive the abusive environment.

She also highlights why it’s essential to teach children critical thinking, helping them gently explore:

Where did this idea come from?

Did I experience this, or was I told this?

Who benefits from me believing this?

Therapy can be helpful, but only with professionals who truly understand coercive control. Otherwise, it can increase shame, reinforce false narratives, and put the child in emotionally damaging positions.

Dr. Christine also previews her next video, where she’ll discuss how certain well-intended protective-parent behaviors can unintentionally lead a child to identify with the aggressor — and how to shift those dynamics with compassion and awareness.

💛 If this resonates, please subscribe, share, and help support families navigating these painful dynamics.
You are not alone.

Dr. Christine explains how children experience somatic cues:
“My belly hurts… my head feels bad… something inside me doesn’t feel right,”
and how these sensations often reveal their discomfort or fear, even when they’re unable to articulate what’s happening in unsafe environments.

She also discusses the heartbreaking reality of being forced by systems to send your child to the predatory parent, even when the child is showing clear signs of distress. This is a form of systemic coercive control, and it leaves protective parents feeling dismissed, blamed, or entirely unheard.

Dr. Christine shares how her new children’s book, Every Moment of Every Day, helps parents support their child through these dysregulated transitions, offering validation, connection, and somatic awareness for little ones living with these complex experiences.

Why children become dysregulated before or after unsafe parenting time

episodes.title: The Predatory Parent: Traits, Tactics & Why It Gets Worse Over Time
episodes.description:
In today’s video, Dr. Christine Cocchiola breaks down the reality of the predatory parent — individuals who use coercive control, narcissistic tactics, manipulation, and system exploitation to harm their partners and children.

She explains why coercive control is the underpinning of all abuse and why these dynamics don’t start with physical violence. Instead, they begin with power, control, psychological domination, and escalate over time — especially after separation, when the abuser feels their power slipping.

Dr. Christine dives into the traits often seen in predatory parents:

Narcissism (grandiosity, victimhood, no genuine empathy)

Machiavellianism (manipulation, flying monkeys, DARVO)

Psychopathy (willingness to break the law, stalking, tracking devices, harassment)

Sadism (deriving satisfaction from causing emotional harm)

She emphasizes an essential truth: abusers weaponize children because they know children are what matter most to the protective parent.

Understanding these patterns is the first step toward clarity, safety planning, and protecting both yourself and your children.

episodes.title: What are the Costs & Benefits | The Hidden Costs of Going Back to Court with Dr. Cocchiola
episodes.description:
In this episode, Dr. Christine Cocchiola unpacks one of the toughest questions protective parents face: should you take the abuser back to court when your child resists visitation or therapy? A mom with a 16-year-old who no longer wants to visit and a 19-year-old off at college wonders if mandating therapy and enforcing shared custody through the court is the right step.

Dr. Cocchiola explores the costs and benefits of returning to court. While the desire to prove to your child that you fought for them is powerful, the hidden costs can be devastating. Abusers often retaliate by intensifying control and punishment, targeting the child as a weapon. This leaves the developing brain depleted, unable to regulate, connect, or process. The child may then appear aligned with the abuser not out of preference, but out of sheer survival.

Parents must ask: is the fight in court truly in the best interest of the child, or does it risk greater harm? Dr. Cocchiola stresses the importance of weighing these choices carefully. Sometimes letting go of the rope is not giving up, but protecting your child from further suffering. It sends the message that your love and safety are constant, your door is always open, and you understand why they made the choices they did under coercion.

Dr. Zuckerman shares her deep expertise from years of working with survivors, offering insight into the traits that make individuals vulnerable, the subtle and overt patterns of abuse, and the critical need for better clinician training to identify these behaviors. As the founder of The Z Group, host of the Next Up: Narcissism podcast, and author of two interactive workbooks—Find Your Calm and Find Good Habits—Dr. Zuckerman brings practical tools and real-world strategies for reclaiming your power, setting boundaries, and rebuilding your life. episodes.title: Coercive Control and Abuse Explained by Dr. Cocchiola
episodes.description:
Coercive control is the root of nearly every form of abuse, from domestic violence and child abuse to sex trafficking, racism, and even terrorism. In this episode, Dr. Cocchiola explains why recognizing patterns of power and control is critical for therapists, parents, and anyone navigating high-conflict relationships. Drawing on research showing that 68% of mass shooters had a history of domestic abuse, she warns how these behaviors reveal character traits that escalate over time. Dr. Cocchiola outlines the differences between abusers and victims: abusers think in rigid black-and-white terms, while victims often show empathy, optimism, and a tendency to forgive even at their own expense. Through the dominance lens, you will learn how to identify covert and overt forms of control, such as one partner managing all the finances, constant mockery, or using a loved one’s vulnerabilities against them. She stresses that true accountability requires mutuality, reciprocity, and immediate behavioral change, not excuses, minimization, or forcing the victim to accommodate abuse. This talk also challenges cultural biases, especially the higher standards often placed on women in therapy, and emphasizes why children, like adults, should never be made to live with or excuse abusive behavior.

episodes.title: Escaping the Narcissist: How to Identify, Survive, and Heal from Manipulative Abuse with Vanessa M. Reiser, LCSW, Therapist, Author, Narcissistic/Cult Abuse Expert
episodes.description: In this episode of Perfect Prey, I sit down with Vanessa Reiser, LCSW, a renowned psychotherapist, speaker, and advocate who has dedicated her career to helping survivors of narcissistic abuse and coercive control reclaim their lives. Vanessa is the founder of Tell a Therapist, a nationwide telehealth platform, and the author of Narcissistic Abuse: A Therapist’s Guide, a groundbreaking resource that not only unpacks the devastating impact of narcissistic and cult abuse but also offers clinicians the training and tools they need to support survivors in the healing process. Together, we explore what coercive control looks like in real life. We talk about why certain people are more vulnerable to narcissistic abuse, the toll it takes on mental health, and how survivors can begin to recognize the patterns and break free. We also shine a light on the unique challenges survivors face in family court when narcissistic abuse is involved, and why therapist training in this area is so urgently needed. Vanessa’s book is an essential guide for professionals and survivors alike, offering not just insight but hope—that recovery is possible, and that healing from narcissistic abuse is about reclaiming your voice, your power, and your life. episodes.title: The Psychology of Coercive Control: Cognitive Dissonance and Trauma Bonds Explained
episodes.description: In this episode of Perfect Prey: A Coercive Control Podcast, Dr. Christine Cocchiola sits down with Dr. Peter Salerno to take a deeper look at the hidden dynamics of coercive control and the psychological abuse that entraps partners and children in cycles of fear, confusion, and dependency. We explore the defining traits of coercive controllers, how they manipulate both adult and child victims, and why survivors often struggle with cognitive dissonance, a mental conflict that can keep them tethered to abusive relationships long after the harm is clear. Together, we discuss the traumatic impact of cognitive dissonance, how abusers condition children to adopt distorted beliefs, and what protective strategies parents can use to safeguard their children’s well-being. You’ll also hear about the crucial role of trauma-informed therapy, ways to respond intentionally to children’s conditioned behaviors, and how survivors can begin to break free from the psychological grip of coercive control. This conversation sheds light on the complex psychological dynamics of abuse and offers practical steps for supporting both adults and children who have been targeted by coercive controllers. If you’ve ever felt trapped in a relationship that left you doubting your own reality, or if you’re working to protect children from ongoing manipulation, this episode will give you clarity, tools, and hope for the path forward. episodes.title: Understanding Narcissism and Coercive Control with Mark Vicente
episodes.description: In this episode of Perfect Prey, I sit down with filmmaker and NXIVM Whistleblower, Mark Vicente, to explore the insidious nature of narcissism and coercive control. Known for his role in exposing the NXIVM cult and for his upcoming documentary Narcissist Playbook, Mark brings a rare blend of lived experience and narrative insight to a conversation that is both deeply personal and profoundly educational. Together, we examine how narcissistic abuse thrives on confusion, manipulation, and silence. Coercive control isn't always visible—often it hides in plain sight, eroding a survivor’s sense of self through emotional, psychological, and sometimes spiritual abuse. Mark shares how he came to recognize the patterns of power and control he endured, and why storytelling and awareness are key to dismantling these dynamics. As a licensed clinical social worker and survivor of coercive control myself, this conversation is one I know will resonate. We talk about the trauma of emotional abuse, the grooming tactics abusers use to gain and maintain control, and the long road to healing after escaping these toxic dynamics. Mark’s courage and clarity offer validation to those still trying to make sense of what happened to them, and hope to those who are just beginning to find their voice. This is more than a podcast episode… it’s a call to awareness, to healing, and to action. Tune in to better understand the trauma of coercive control and narcissistic relationships, and to remember that your truth is the first step toward freedom. For years, she believed her father was her rock—until he started giving her advice on how to beat the system. That’s when it hit her. The very tactics she was protecting her children from… were the same ones her father used on her mother. She hadn’t seen her mom in years. But in that moment, everything clicked. episodes.title: Trauma Bonding with Dr. Nadine Macaluso
episodes.description: Trauma bonding can keep us locked in an abusive relationship. It’s a neurological response to the abuse that creates significant vulnerability. It happens to our children too—they may become bonded to their abuser (your abuser). About Dr. Nadine: Dr. Nadine Macaluso, known to her patients as Dr. Nae, is the real-life inspiration behind Naomi Belfort's character in "The Wolf of Wall Street." She survived a turbulent eight-year marriage to Jordan Belfort, marked by abuse, greed, and trauma. Following her experiences, Dr. Macaluso relocated to California. Her journey of trauma and healing inspired her to return to school at age 39, where she earned her Master's in counseling and a Ph.D. in somatic psychotherapy. She further specialized with a two-year postdoctoral training in the Neuro-affective Relational Model (NARM). As a therapist, Dr. Macaluso combines her education and personal experiences to help others heal from trauma. Her practice focuses on assisting patients in connecting with their authentic selves, fostering confidence, resilience, and agency. Dr. Macaluso firmly believes in the potential for post-traumatic growth, instilling hope in her patients and guiding them to reach their potential in life and love. --- 🔸Follow Dr. Christine on IG: www.instagram.com/dr.cocchiola_coercivecontrol 🔸Visit her website: https://coercivecontrolconsulting.com 🔸Become a Certified Trauma-Informed Protective Parent in this intensive educational program with an option for LIVE coaching/support to guide protective parents as they navigate the stormy seas of parenting a child who has been coercively controlled. 🔸Sign up here: https://go.drcocchiola.com/pppwselfstudy

People are ends unto themselves and not pawns in someone else’s games" - unless of course, we are dealing with a coercive controller [narcissistic abuser]. Then everyone is fair game - especially our children. In this in-depth episode, Dr. Cocchiola explores how individuals, often narcissistic abusers or coercive controllers, prey on empathetic and loyal individuals. She then expands this concept to children who may be more susceptible to this form of manipulation due to the power dynamics with parents or guardians. She emphasizes the importance of understanding these manipulations and the dangers they pose within families. Dr. Cocchiola examines the coercive controller's tactics, from manipulating children and weaponizing them against the protective parent to using children to fill their ego tanks. She also discusses the damage this form of abuse causes, defining it as betrayal trauma and complex trauma, and echoes a strong need for recognition and intervention.
